Since Mohtadi demonstrated the first fully inorganic and halide-free Mg electrolytes, enabling reversible Mg plating and stripping, in 2012, liquid electrolytes based on magnesium borohydride, Mg(BH 4) 2, have received significant attention (Mohtadi et al., 2012). Because of the reductive stability of the
BH
4
-
anion, Mg(BH 4) 2 also arouses the interest to develop as solid Mg ion conductor. However, the conductivity of Mg(BH 4) 2 is very low at room temperature (10 −12 S cm −1 at 30°C), resulted by the firm tetrahedral sites of
BH
4
-
hindering the smooth migration of Mg ions. Proper modification of Mg(BH 4) 2 are thus necessary to improve the conductivity.
